p: In another relevant work called “Rapamycin-loaded lipid nanocapsules induce selective inhibition of the mTORC1-signaling pathway in glioblastoma cells,” Garcion et al. developed lipid nanocapsules containing rapamycin, a poorly water-soluble inhibitor of mTOR phosphorylation at Ser(2448), for potential application in cancer, particularly in glioblastomas combined with radiotherapy. Inhibition of mTOR phosphorylation down regulates a serine protein kinase (Akt) involved in the regulation of the progression of cancer cells. The work suggests that the new developed nanocarrier for rapamycin could be used as radiosensitizer and could be used for local–regional or peripherical administration for the treatment of glioblastomas.
